oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Le mystere de la charite de Jeanne D'Arc
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 500 copies of this book were printed by Victor Hammer with the assistance of Jacob Hammer. The engraving of Jeanne D'Arc was cut on metal by Victor Hammer and is "based on a drawing scribbled by a clerk of the Parliament of Paris in the margin of a record of 1429 which mentions the lifting of the seige of Orleans"--Colophon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Péguy, Charles, 1873-1914
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Joan, of Arc, Saint, 1412-1431 --Drama; France --History --Charles VII, 1422-1461 --Drama
Arts & Entertainment

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: handwritten comments in pencil; 236 p. : 24 cm.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wells College press
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Depicts an announcement in the December 1940 Wells College Alumnae News regarding the creation of the Wells College Press under the direction of Victor Hammer. The announcement also announces the first book to be about Wells College verse (later titled Young Voices) and whether people would like to purchase it for no more than $1.50.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wells College

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: College women train and work for victory
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An article that includes a picture of Wells College students using the Wells College Press during World War II. The caption reads “If bombs destroy power presses, Wells College students well be equipped to set type by hand and operate hand presses.”
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Griswold, Berneice
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945; Wells College, Aurora, N. Y.; Wells College Press
Military & War; Education; People

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young voices: a book of Wells College verse
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A collection of Wells College student verse from 1875 to 1942. It was the first book printed on the Wells College Press. "Designed by Victor and Jacob Hammer in 14-point Emerson type. Set by hand and printed by Jacob Hammer at the Wells College Press"--Colophon.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dialogue on the Uncial between a paleographer and a printer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This 350 copy edition was created by Victor Hammer as a keepsake for the Society of the Typographic Arts in Chicago. It explains some of Hammer's thoughts regarding the American Uncial, a typeface he designed and created.
